events.originalText: Nepal was struck by a magnitude 7.8 earthquake, killing more than 8,000 people, including 22 from avalanches on Mount Everest.
events.subtitle: April 2015 Nepal earthquake
events.headline: Nepal Struck by 7.8 Magnitude Earthquake, Over 8,000 Dead

events.originalText: Violeta Chamorro took office as president of Nicaragua, becoming the first female head of state in the Americas to have been elected in her own right.
events.subtitle: Violeta Chamorro
events.headline: Violeta Chamorro Becomes First Female President of Nicaragua

events.originalText: The first issue of The Jakarta Post was published in Indonesia.
events.subtitle: The Jakarta Post
events.headline: First Issue of The Jakarta Post Published in Indonesia

events.originalText: Falklands War: British prime minister Margaret Thatcher told journalists in Downing Street to rejoice upon hearing news of the successful recapture of South Georgia from Argentine forces.
events.subtitle: Falklands War
events.headline: Margaret Thatcher Celebrates Recapture of South Georgia from Argentina

events.originalText: 109 individuals were arrested in a police raid on a gay bar near Chicago.
events.subtitle: Fun Lounge police raid
events.headline: 109 Arrested in Police Raid on Gay Bar near Chicago

events.originalText: The U.S. Navy submarine Triton (pictured) completed the first submerged circumnavigation of the world.
events.subtitle: United States Navy
events.headline: U.S. Navy Submarine Triton Completes First Submerged Circumnavigation

events.originalText: Two passenger trains collided in Naperville, Illinois, leaving 45 people dead and some 125 injured.
events.subtitle: Naperville train disaster
events.headline: Two Trains Collide in Naperville, Illinois, 45 Dead

events.originalText: Gladys Elinor Watkins consecrated the carillon of the National War Memorial in New Zealand (dedication pictured).
events.subtitle: Gladys Elinor Watkins
events.headline: Gladys Elinor Watkins Consecrates Carillon of National War Memorial in New Zealand

events.originalText: At the San Remo conference, the principal Allies of World War I passed a resolution allocating League of Nations mandates for the administration of former Ottoman territories in the Middle East.
events.subtitle: San Remo conference
events.headline: Allies Allocate League of Nations Mandates for Former Ottoman Territories

events.originalText: A march by blind people from across the UK to protest at poor working conditions ended at Trafalgar Square.
events.subtitle: 1920 blind march
events.headline: Blind People March to Trafalgar Square to Protest Poor Working Conditions

events.originalText: First World War: The Australian and New Zealand Army Corps landed at Anzac Cove while British and French troops landed at Cape Helles to begin the Allied invasion of the Gallipoli peninsula in the Ottoman Empire.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: Australian and New Zealand Army Corps Land at Anzac Cove

events.originalText: Mingâ€“Qing transition: The Ming dynasty of China fell when the Chongzhen Emperor committed suicide during a peasant rebellion led by Li Zicheng.
events.subtitle: Transition from Ming to Qing
events.headline: Ming Dynasty Falls as Chongzhen Emperor Commits Suicide

events.originalText: First English Civil War: Despite being vastly outnumbered, a Parliamentarian force under James Chudleigh defeated a Royalist army near Okehampton, Devon.
events.subtitle: First English Civil War
events.headline: Parliamentarian Force Defeats Royalist Army near Okehampton, Devon

events.originalText: Leo III was attacked by partisans of his predecessor Adrian I, but was rescued and taken to Charlemagne, as described in the epic Karolus magnus et Leo papa.
events.subtitle: Pope Leo III
events.headline: Leo III Attacked by Partisans of Adrian I, Rescued by Charlemagne

events.originalText: The Abbasid army won a decisive victory over the forces of rebelling Armenian princes at the Battle of Bagrevand.
events.subtitle: Abbasid Caliphate
events.headline: Abbasid Army Wins Battle of Bagrevand Against Armenian Princes
